summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff regarding press guidance for the trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. It details the schedule for jury charge and opening statements, notes that several witnesses will testify under pseudonyms, and lists the charges and maximum penalties Maxwell faces.

persons.name: Nicholas Biase
persons.context: Appears as a sender/recipient in email chain coordinating press guidance for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Janis Echenberg
persons.context: Appears as a sender/recipient in email chain providing information about trial logistics and press guidance.

persons.name: James Margolin
persons.context: Copied on emails as a contact for media regarding access to government exhibits for the Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Eric Blachman
persons.context: Mentioned as having reserved a seat in the courtroom for the trial openings.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant on trial, charged with conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to entice and traffic minors for illegal sexual activity.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the co-conspirator with Ghislaine Maxwell in the charges of enticing minors for illegal sex acts.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over the U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell trial at the Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged with conspiring with Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in illegal sex acts.
Judge Alison Nathan is presiding over the criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.
They are corresponding as colleagues within the U.S. Attorney's Office to coordinate press guidance for the Maxwell trial.

events.title: Jury Charge and Opening Statements in U.S. v. Maxwell
events.description: Scheduled for 9:30 a.m., involving jury charge followed by opening statements in the criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Final Pretrial Conference in U.S. v. Maxwell
events.description: Held before Judge Alison Nathan as the final conference before the trial.

locations: Courtroom 318, 40 Foley Square (Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse)
Overflow Courtrooms 110, 506, 905, and 906 of the Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell faced six criminal counts, including conspiracy to commit sex trafficking of minors (max 40 years) and sex trafficking of minors.
The court granted a government motion allowing several witnesses, including victims, to testify under pseudonyms to protect their identities.
The trial was scheduled to begin with jury charge and opening statements on November 26, 2021, before Judge Alison Nathan.
The press guidance explicitly urges media to respect witness privacy and not identify sex crime victims without consent.
Government exhibits for the trial were to be provided exclusively through an SDNY file share, requiring media to establish access.
